Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department

analytic.title: Fuzzy Clustering: A Historical Perspective

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Fuzzy sets emerged in 1965 in a paper by Lotfi Zadeh. In 1969 Ruspini published a seminal paper that has become the basis of most fuzzy clustering algorithms. His ideas established the underlying structure for fuzzy partitioning, and also described and exemplified the first algorithm for accomplishing it. Bezdek developed the general case of the fuzzy c-means model in 1973. Many branches of this tree grew from 1969 to 1993. Then another watershed paper in fuzzy clustering appeared: 1556-603x/19Â©2019ieee FeBRUARY 2019 | ieee CompUtAtionAl intelligenCe mAgAzine 45

Krishnapuram and Keller's work on possibilistic clustering. This tree has also developed many branches, and together, these two topics comprise two thirds (of the conceptual field) of soft clustering (the other third belongs to probabilistic clustering in its many guises). Another important class of fuzzy and possibilistic methods, known as generalized clustering, were later developed, based on the idea of stressing the internal nature of clusters rather than solely on metric notions or on the sharing of some significant traits. This article reviews some of the key highlights of fuzzy and possibilistic clustering. This is not a comprehensive survey: that would require an article the size of an encyclopedia and an army of well-informed authors. The best we can do here is to give readers a small glimpse of the overall reach and span of Zadeh's idea in the vast jungle that is fuzzy cluster analysis.

1. Introduction t his paper briefly reviews the development of a vast array of computational methods, known collectively as fuzzy clustering. Length limits imposed by its format preclude the preparation of even a skimpy survey of this vast field. We aim, rather, to note key early milestones in the development of the technology, together with the description of the underlying ideas, leading to a presentation of the state of the art and of current key problems that need to be addressed to assure its further evolution.

Why do we classify? Sentient organisms, even those that are very simple, are confronted throughout their existence by a large number of objects in their environment. The variety of living environments is not only due to their size but also their diversity and complexity. This complexity, captured by multiple organism sensors, is formally represented by a potentially large number of object description variables. Dealing with the large number and variety of objects and variables requires the ability to organize them into useful classes that are the basis for simple and complex behaviors. Recent neurological studies strongly suggest that human brains are wired to represent thousands of objects and action categories.
Furthermore, and of extreme importance to the subject of this paper, the semantic space so represented is continuous [1].

Grouping objects into categories that share some key feature or variable range is a necessary skill that assures survival of the conscious classifier. Given the wide diversity and complexity of the entities (objects, relations, actions) to be classified it should not be surprising that myriad formal methods have been proposed to summarize entities of interest as a collection of classes sharing common traits. Basic to this process is the notion of indistinguishability, that is, the idea that, for a particular decision making purpose, the individuals in a class need not be differentiated from each other.

We aim here to discuss the problem of classifying objects on the basis of various notions of similarity, distance, or indistinguishability. Our historical review is focused on classification methods based on the theory of fuzzy sets and related formalisms, such as fuzzy logic and possibility theory. It is important to note that we will not concern ourselves with the construction of classifiers, by means of supervised methods, in situations where the classes are known and are described either through a set of classificatory axioms or, more commonly, through subsets of known examples of each of the known classes. We discuss, instead, methods for unsupervised classification based on application of concepts and ideas from fuzzy-set theory. The description of this latter class as being unsupervised is somewhat misleading and motivated solely by the need to distinguish its techniques from methods where the classes are already known and the task is to devise algorithms that map object descriptions into their classifications. In clustering, the aim is to employ a different type of supervision or guidance-provided by notions of similarity or of trait sharing-to discover classes that may shed light on the structure of the underlying system.

Even when the objective of the classification is not the emulation of an existing categorization system but, rather, the discovery of a new one, there may be a wide diversity of goals driving the taxonomical purpose. This diversity was noted in the early years of pattern recognition research by authors who remarked on the wide variety of situations that occurred in practice, as seen in Figure 1 [2].

Quite often we aim to discover clusters having elements that are similar to others within the cluster but dissimilar to those outside it. This objective, motivating the majority of early clustering methods, seeks to reduce the complexity of a multivariate dataset by its reduction to a manageable number of clusters, each having members that resemble each other.

The key idea here is that the ensuing loss of information will not be harmful to the objectives of the exercise in system understanding. This view, seeking to maximize utility-based measures of classificatory value, has also been found to be at the core of important interpretations of the basic notions of fuzzy set and fuzzy logic [3], [4].

A significant conceptual enhancement of the notion of cluster as a set of points that resemble each other while being different from points in other clusters is the consideration of internal cluster structure. A number of generalized clustering methods are based on the notion that clusters should have some form of cohesion that may not be expressible in terms of binary measures of similarity [5]. As consideration of general cohesion measures usually leads to complex, intractable, and computational problems, general notions of cohesion are replaced by requirements that the classes resemble structures of interest in a multidimensional Euclidean space [6].

Beyond partitioning large datasets into subsets of interest, we are many times interested in the relations among the clusters themselves. From this viewpoint, a clustering is not merely a collection of interesting or useful clusters of a sample but, actually, a structure that, as a whole, yields important insights into the system being studied. These structures, comprising not only data subsets but also important relations between them, often allow objects to belong to multiple classes while not requiring every point to belong to a cluster.

div.head: Fuzzy Sets and Fuzzy Clustering
div.p: The early development of clustering algorithms was primarily motivated by the desire to formalize and extend the classification structures of biological taxonomy, or systematics. The classification system, differentiating and relating species, was originally formulated by the famous Swedish physician and botanist Linnaeus [7], who provided an enduring hierarchical structure, substantially increasing the understanding of their roles and interactions. This taxonomy, later enhanced and interpreted through the years by evolutionary and genetic knowledge, provided the foundations for early automated methods of numerical classification [8].

Aside. Confusion about the difference between computational approaches to clustering and classification abounds in the pattern recognition literature. Today we call the "classes" of Linnaeus a set of clusters. Psychologists and numerical taxonomists still refer to the labeling of finite sets as "classification." Indeed, the Classification Society is devoted almost entirely to what is now called clustering.

div.head: A. Object Clustering and Relational Clustering
div.p: The starting point of any clustering effort is a collection of objects and some notion (often implicit) of resemblance intended to help the classifier to tell good versus bad classifications. In many cases resemblance between the objects to be classified is given by means of a binary relation representing distance or dissimilarity. For any pair of objects in the initial collection this relation assigns a nonnegative numerical value indicating, for example, whether two objects are similar (i.e., distance close to zero) and it would be desirable to group them together, or whether they do not resemble each other (i.e., large distance) and thus that it will be a bad idea to put them in the same cluster. In these relational clustering problems the notion of resemblance is, sometimes, given instead by a similarity measure, which may be thought of as a numeric complement of a classical distance function, that is, small distances correspond to high similarities and vice versa.

In other numerical classification problems the notion of similarity is not explicitly given but, rather, objects are specified as vectors in some representation space-usually a p-dimensional Euclidean space . p 0 In these object clustering problems classificatory insights are often provided by some suitable measure of distance defined in the representation space, thus making the problem-after some initial data processing and reduction-equivalent to a relational clustering problem. In other cases, statistical measures of correlation or assumptions about cluster structure provide more or less explicit classification guidelines [9], [10]

The type of data usually dictates the style of clustering, but since any feature vector dataset X can be converted to relational data by the simple expedient of defining ( , ) diss o o x x k j k j = using any vector norm, relational clustering is in some sense a bit more general.

div.head: B. Numerical Classification and Fuzzy Sets
div.p: To a large extent, the early development of numerical clustering methods relied on a variety of heuristics [11] rather than on formal characterizations of the problem with a clear set of assumptions and measurable goals. In the relational clustering problem-then the object of most clustering efforts-the classification goal was usually stated as "partition the set of objects into groups so that all members in the same group are similar while objects in different groups are dissimilar." As Figure 2 shows for a dataset in , 2 0 this problem as stated, does not have a solution since, in that case, any partition will necessarily put close points in different sets [12]. This essential impossibility demanded the utilization of a richer representation scheme than that provided by classical partitions thus leading to the consideration [13] of a new methodology for the description of vagueness and imprecision.

div.head: C. Fuzzy Sets
div.p: Fuzzy sets were introduced by Zadeh [14] called the degree of belongingness or membership of the point x to the fuzzy set S, measures the amount to which x is a member of S. Values could range from 0 for points not in S to 1 for points said to be in the core of S. We will not discuss the theory of fuzzy sets and related formalisms, such as possibility theory or fuzzy logic, beyond pointing out that it is formally and conceptually different from probability theory. At the formal level, the formulas that define set composition and complement are truth functional, or fully dependent on the degree of belongingness of the arguments, unlike those of probability theory. The formulas proposed by Zadeh for the intersection, union, and complement of fuzzy sets S and T were: These basic equations have been expanded to include a wide variety of extensions of the truth-value tables of the classical set theory [15]- [17]. At the conceptual level, the main ideas of the theory are grounded on notions of "proximity to truth" [18] rather than by those stemming from the study of the chance of events. Due to its ability to describe classes with imprecise boundaries the concept of fuzzy set strongly suggested utility for the nascent field of pattern recognition as proposed in 1966 by Bellman et al. [19].

div.head: D. Fuzzy Clustering
div.p: The advent of the concept of fuzzy set provided a richer framework for the specification of the relations between points and clusters [13]. Rather than conceiving the solution of a clustering problem as the assignment of each data point to one, and only one, cluster, the fuzzy clustering approach regards it as the discovery of a mapping U from the dataset X to the multidimensional cube [ , ] , 0
div.formula: 1 c that is, : { , , } U X x xn 1 7 f = [ , ] : ( ( ), , ( )) u u 0 1 x x x c k k c k 1 7 f for all , , k n 1 x X k !
div.p: # # where c is the (assumed) number of clusters. A point xk fully belonging to the j-th cluster will have ( ) , u 1 x j k = while some points may have positive degrees of belongingness to several clusters. In the initial formulation proposed by Ruspini [13], the degrees of belongingness of each point to each cluster were assumed to satisfy the equation:
div.formula: ( ) : . u 1 for all x x X i k i c k 1 ! = = / (1)
div.p: Equation ( 1) generalizes the relation, initially proposed by Zadeh [14], to define the degrees of membership of any point x X ! to a fuzzy set S and its complement , S r ( )
div.formula: ( ) . 1 x x S S n n + = r
div.p: Due to its resemblance to the additive law of probabilities, ( 1) is often called the probabilistic constraint. This expression, together with other uses of probabilistic notation in Ruspini's paper, led some to question whether fuzzy clusters were just a disguise for probability distributions. The intent, however, was quite clear and did not lend itself to easy confusion. The objective was to provide a richer description of the nature of the dataset being classified rather than to discover some underlying random process resulting in its generation. Representation of a point x belonging to a fuzzy set A to the degree 0.5 and to the fuzzy set B to the same degree is intended to indicate that the point lies midway between the cores of A and B, rather than to make a statistical assumption about a hidden aleatory process having equal chances of assigning x to one of two distinct classes A and B. The key conceptual distinction, studied later in detail by Ruspini, when proposing a semantics for fuzzy sets and fuzzy logic [4], lies in the difference between a representation approach that measures the degree to which a statement can be said to be true (e.g., how true is the statement "John is a millionaire" if his assets amount to $999,999) versus a description of the relative number of times that such a statement is found to be true or false when sampling individuals from some space. The latter is, of course, the basis for probability theory, while the former is related to the notion of truthlikeness [18], [20]. This view of degrees of membership as descriptors of a continuous space of clustering possibilities results in a framework where problems, such as that illustrated in Figure 2, which cannot be treated by conventional methods, are now feasible of solution within a richer formal structure that allows objects to belong to multiple clusters to various degrees. Beyond seeking to gain representational ability the introduction of fuzzy clustering also had a practical motivation. The development of formal classification methods, beyond various scope-limited heuristics, strongly suggested the introduction of measures of clustering quality. These degrees of clustering performance were provided by measures , J(U: ) X having as arguments the dataset X being classified and a particular partitioning U. For fixed , X the performance index J(U: )

X could be employed to compare the relative quality of several partitions. In the relational clustering problems first considered by Ruspini, dependence on the object set X was represented by means of a distance function D defined between pairs of vectors in X or by a related fuzzy similarity function [21]. Having a performance index naturally leads to the desire to find a U that is not bettered by any other alternative. In a classical framework where points are assigned to one and only one cluster, this problem is typically formulated as a difficult integer optimization problem where solutions must meet constraints have values restricted to be either 0 or 1. In the richer fuzzy extension, however, the optimization problem is a continuous-variable problem tractable using the powerful tools of continuous mathematical analysis.

div.head: E. Early Methods
div.p: The earliest reference to the use of fuzzy sets in numerical pattern recognition was Bellman, Kalaba and Zadeh [19]. Apparently Bill Wee wrote the first Ph.D. thesis about fuzzy pattern recognition in 1967 [23]. In 1968 Flake and Turner [24] discussed a method for constructing a hierarchy of fuzzy subsets they called clusters. However, the bellwether of fuzzy clustering appeared one year later [13]. Posed in the context of relational clustering, Ruspini considered the general classification, or data reduction, problem to be equivalent to the determination of a fuzzy partition whose columns map objects in a finite set { , , }
div.formula: X x xn 1 f = into the c-dimensional cube [ , ] ,
div.p: 0 1 c where , c the number of clusters, was assumed to be known, For any object vector xk the k-th column of U (a matrix in the set Mfcn at (4.2)), viz., the column vector1 ( ) ( ( ), , ( )) ,

div.p: represents the labeling of xk in terms of its memberships to each cluster. In his original paper Ruspini [13] considered several possible characterizations of the grouping problem, all based on the assumption on the availability of a distance function D between pairs of points of X. Among these, the main formulation was based on the utilization of a metric V in the classification space [ , ] 0 1 c and on the identification of a metric-mapping function F such that:

Being a subset of the Euclidean space , p 0 it was natural to select D to be the Euclidean distance in that space. The choice of the function F was, however, more problematic as the distance function D in the object space , X although assumed to have the standard properties of a conventional metric, could have arbitrary values while its counterpart V, defined in a bounded subset of , c 0 was itself bounded. In consideration of this fact, it was assumed that F was a non-decreasing function mapping the nonnegative real line 0 + to itself with ( ) . 0 0 F = After some experimentation F was chosen [12] to be a piecewise linear function of the form:

As, in general, the multiple constraints of Equation ( 2) cannot be satisfied for any clustering function, the problem was posed as that of the minimization of the clustering quality index (objective function);

Through suitable choices of the functions F and V performance index optimization could then be treated as a nonlinear programming problem.

Reliance on parameters assumed to be known beforehand such as the actual (but unknown) number of clusters c has been a continued source of vexation for clustering methods, whether conventional or fuzzy. Many clustering validation methods and associated validity indexes have been advanced to provide insights on the nature of parameters used to define the clustering-quality index or the associated clustering constraints.

The first validity index for fuzzy clustering methods was also proposed by Ruspini [13]. This index, based on the notion of entropy, sought to measure the extent to which a proposed classification contained too many clusters by noting that, in those cases, some otherwise compact clusters would be split into several parts with a high number of points belonging partially to more than one cluster. This index is given by the functional:

div.head: Fuzzy Clustering for Object Data
div.p: We introduce some additional notation for label vectors and partition matrices.

div.head: A. Label Vectors and Partition Matrices
div.p: There are four types of labels (crisp, fuzzy, probabilistic and possibilistic), but only three sets of label vectors in .

div.p: A matrix U in any of these sets is called a partition of a set of objects O because its ik-th entry is as interpreted as the membership of object k in cluster :
div.formula: i ( ), u u o ik i k = where : [ , ] u X 0 1 i 7
div.p: is the function defining the i-th cluster. As noted above, for crisp clusters ui is the characteristic or indicator function of the i-th cluster. Fig. 3 See [25] for a proof. The depiction in Fig. 4 makes the computational difference between hard and fuzzy clustering algorithms explicit. In particular, ALL hard clustering algorithms must jump from vertex to vertex (i.e., the hard c-partitions on n objects) without a continuous path connection, whereas fuzzy (and probabilistic) clustering algorithms can move through the continuous domain of the (solid) polytope during iteration towards an optimal model. See [25] or [26] for a more complete discussion of the geometry and theory of the two sets at (4.2) and (4.3).

div.head: B. The c-Means Models
div.formula: ( , : ) . U J V X , M 1 U V cp hcn minimize 0 ! ! " ,(5b)
div.p: The first written work (at least in English) describing a batch version of an iterative algorithm for minimizing J (U, ; ) V X 1 was given by Lloyd [31]. A similar procedure was discussed by Cox in [32]. The first discussion of J (U, ; ) V X 1 as a clustering criterion is widely credited to Steinhaus [33]. Lloyd acknowledged that his method apparently appeared in a paper written by Lukaszewicz and Steinhaus [34]. There are many ways to attempt minimization of , J (U, ) V 1 but none are as popular as simple alternating iteration through the necessary conditions for U and .

V Since U is discrete (cf. Figure 4), J (U, ) V 1 cannot possess joint local minima in the usual sense, so the iteration scheme is not quite alternating optimization (AO). This basic approach is often referred to as Lloyd's algorithm. There are literally tens of thousands of papers that use Lloyd's algorithm or a relative of it that are simply called c-means (or k-means).

In 1962, Sebestyen [27] defined a sequential clustering procedure for batch data. His scheme required one pass through X, was initialized at , c 1 = and required a user-defined threshold T which essentially controlled the size of the clusters grown by the process. In 1967, MacQueen [28] defined sHCM (calling it simply "k-means") and specified a way to process batch data one at a time. This was a slight variant of Sebestyen's approach wherein one pass is made through X without a threshold, but this version required pre-specification of . c In 1973, Duda and Hart [29] presented a "Basic Minimum Squared Error (BMSE)" version of this idea. In 1975, Hartigan [11] formalized Sebestyen's algorithm as the batch leader algorithm.

Fuzzy generalization of batch HCM began with the seminal paper of Dunn [35]. First, he was inspired by Ball and Hall's ISO-DATA algorithm [36] for generating crisp clusters using J (U, ) V 1 as the defining criterion. And second, he saw how to incorporate the idea of Ruspini's fuzzy partition into a generalization of the classical problem. His work resulted in the special case of fuzzy c-means (FCM) for the membership weighting exponent . m 2 = The norm used in (5a) was (and usually still is) the Euclidean norm, but Dunn showed how to incorporate more general norms into his fuzzy generalization of . J (U, ; ) V X
In particular, Dunn allowed the norm in his work to be any inner product norm to make differentiation of x v

div.p: with respect to vi tractable. Dunn also made important contributions connecting one of Zadeh's ideas to relational clustering [37].

The connection between classical HCM and Dunn's special case of FCM was completed by Bezdek, who defined the general case ( ) m 1 $ of FCM in [38]. The objective function and optimization problem defining the fuzzy c-means (FCM) model are

This established FCM as a true generalization of HCM. Dunn and Bezdek both (mistakenly) used the term fuzzy ISODATA in their early papers. Ball and Hall had heuristic devices in ISODATA for creating and merging clusters (dynamically changing the value of c during iteration), but none of the "fuzzy ISODATA" papers had these features. The first convergence proof of the Picard iteration scheme for AO of J (U, ; ) V X m was presented in [37]. Studies of various theoretical aspects of FCM appear in [39], [40], [57].

div.head: C. Early Relatives and Applications of FCM
div.p: Clusters defined by objective functions almost always take mathematical substance via distances, which induce topological structure on .

p 0 This often forces the criterion function to unwittingly favor clusters having the basic shape of their metric topology, even when no clusters are present! Generalization of FCM to address this problem has taken three distinct tracks. First, there are many models that attempt to match the shape distribution of the points in X better than basic FCM by alteration of the distance
div.formula: . x v k i A 2 -
div.p: Second, a different way to attempt shape-matching is to alter the type of mathematical prototypes in the model, replacing the points
div.formula: { , , } V v vc cp 1 0 f 1 =
div.p: with more general structures such as lines, planes, hyperquadrics, etc. And third, the notion of the fuzzy partition itself can be replaced by the more general idea of the possibilistic partition.

The inner product norm x v 5) forces all of the clusters in X to have roughly the same "cloud-like," A-norm geometry. This problem was first addressed in a very important paper by Gustafson and Kessel [41], who introduced the idea of allowing the norm-inducing matrix A to vary from cluster to cluster. They let each cluster assume a best-match shape via individual norms { } Ai that adapted to the shapes of individual clusters during AO iteration. Information about the shape of the i-th cluster resides in the eigenstructure of Ai. They recognized that the necessary conditions used by AO to optimize their model were in some ways very similar to the well-known maximum likelihood equations (MLEs) used by the expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm to optimize the Gaussian mixture model (GMM, [42]). The fundamental importance of Gustafson and Kessel's work was to show the way towards modifications and improvements of the basic FCM model. See [43] for ways to solve (6) when
div.formula: k i A 2 - in (
x v k i A 2
div.p: is replaced by non-inner product norms. The second path to generalization is to replace the point prototypes in equation ( 5) with more general geometric entities. The earliest reference to the explicit use of non-point prototypes in connection with FCM was [44], which contained a primitive method for fitting fuzzy clusters with lines in the plane. The fuzzy c-varieties (FCV) models [45], [46] grew out of this effort, and were the first generalizations of FCM that explicitly used non-point prototypes (specifically, linear varieties) called fuzzy c-Varieties (FCV). Gunderson proposed a way to make FCV adaptive, so that different clusters could be fitted with linear varieties having different dimensions [47]. Coray [48] suggested the use of circular prototypes-that is, shell-like structures. This line of research evolved into a long chain of more and more sophisticated prototypes and AO algorithms: fuzzy c-shells [49]; fuzzy c-spherical shells [50]; fuzzy c-ellipsoidal shells and fuzzy c-quadric shells [51]; shell prototypes corresponding to level sets of any norm [52]; and fuzzy c-regression models [53].

The use of fuzzy clustering for rule-based induction began when Sugeno and Yasakawa used FCM to estimate membership functions in the output space [54]. Clustering with the GK algorithm in both input and output spaces was introduced by Babuska and Verbruggen to identify Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy systems with linear consequents [55], [56]. Kaymak and Babuska introduced the idea of merging compatible clusters to identify rules that could be combined to simplify the resulting rule base [57]. Yoshinara et al. [58] used FCV and Chiu [59] used Yager's mountain method for rule extraction. Setnes showed used supervised clustering for rule extraction in [60].

div.head: D. Qualitative Object Description
div.p: Another important class of fuzzy clustering methods was introduced in 1999 by Ruspini and Zwir to produce descriptions of complex objects (e.g., time series, large molecules, genetic material) at various levels of detail [6], [61]. The generated descriptions were approximate or qualitative, taking advantage of the ability of fuzzy sets to describe objects by their similarity to certain structures deemed to be interesting by domain specialists. For example, a part of a large biomolecule may be described as "cylindrical" or "having a protruding arm." Closely related to the notion of perception introduced by Zadeh in 1999 [63], the objective of these conceptual clustering methods is to produce qualitative object descriptions in forms (e.g., natural language) close to that employed by humans to describe complex objects rather than in terms of structures mainly devised to represent those objects in a computational setting. For example, a molecule as a hierarchy of parts resembling objects of interest as opposed to a matrix of positions of atoms in 3 D. Beyond uncovering parts of interest of a complex object these methods also sought to relate these parts, each corresponding to a generalized cluster, through predefined interesting relations (e.g., proximity, containment, relative spatial position). The proposed methodology was based on the definition of interesting objects and inter-object relations by general fuzzy models enabling comparison between the degree of matching of a portion of the object being described to paradigmatic model examples. Multi-objective evolutionary computation methods [64] were employed to extract clusters, which could be overlapping, and relations between them. The methodology and its many variations have been successfully applied to problems ranging from gene description [65], gene regulation [66], ontology-based gene annotation [67], and neuropsychiatry [68], [69].

div.head: Possibilistic c-Means and its Relatives
div.p: Despite the successes of various families of FCM algorithms, there was a continuing desire to eliminate the "sum to one" constraints (Equation ( 1)) on the memberships of a vector to all of the clusters needed for optimization of . J (U, ; )

V X m This column constraint prevented the FCM models from signifying that an outlier should have very low membership in all c clusters; or that a vector might deserve high membership in more than one cluster. In other words, the FCM model spreads the degree of belongingness across the clusters better than HCM does, but still does not provide for the possibility of high membership in multiple clusters or low membership in all clusters. Crisp approaches have no choice but to assign anomalies into an individual cluster and fuzzy algorithms can at best force their memberships close to / . c 1 If the number of points being clustered is not huge, this can result in noticeable changes in the cluster prototypes. True outliers can drastically affect the performance of those algorithms.

An early attempt to ameliorate the outlier problem within the FCM framework was to include a noise cluster [70]. In this algorithm all points are considered equidistant from an amorphous noise cluster, and this heuristic distance was large compared with the distances of the "good" points to cluster prototypes. Therefore, noise/outlier points were attracted to the noise cluster. The membership values were still constrained as with FCM, and produce asymmetric cluster membership functions. However, some researchers felt that using this forced constraint did not properly exemplify Zadeh's notion of a cluster being a fuzzy subset of X. Krishnapuram and Keller [30] introduced the idea of relaxing this constraint by adding a second term to ( ) J U, ; , V X m h (the rightmost term in equation ( 7)) that encourages high memberships, thereby relaxing the FCM constraint without forcing memberships to zero. This idea was inspired by noting how a Hopfield Neural Network could be "tricked" into tackling the traveling salesman problem by augmenting its energy function with terms that were minimized when the natural traveling salesman's constraints were enforced.

Nothing about PCM is possibilistic in the true sense of possibility theory [71], [72]. Krishnapuram and Keller chose possibilistic c-means to distinguish it from the sum-to-one fuzzy partitions of FCM. The proof of the fundamental PCM theorem given in [30] mirrors that of the FCM theorem except that the zero distance case is unnecessary. The PCM theorem effectively decouples each cluster when computing membership values; hence they create a natural symmetry in membership. The values { } uik for possibilistic c-partitions generated by PCM (equation (4a)) are called typicalities since they measure how typical a particular input point is to each cluster, i.e., how close the point is to each cluster prototype. Unlike FCM, typicality membership functions are symmetric around each cluster prototype. To take advantage of both FCM memberships and PCM typicalities, some researchers have fused the FCM and PCM objective functions into a single hybrid model that produces both memberships and typicalities simultaneously. Pal et al. [73] is an example of a fuzzy possibilistic c-means algorithm.

Since all clusters are decoupled in the PCM formulation, the cluster centers have the freedom to seek out dense regions of feature space, and so, the PCM algorithm is actually a mode seeking technique. This can be either good news or bad news. Barni et al. [74] pointed out that PCM can find co-incident clusters because there is nothing to stop two cluster centers from moving into the same dense cloud. They had a dataset where they expected c clusters (actually, they had c class labels). Using m 2 = and their initialization, PCM terminated at a number of distinct clusters less than .

c Krishnapuram and Keller subsequently [75] argued that while there might be c class labels, the features extracted for clustering might not support that many clusters, particularly using Euclidean distance. They pointed out that the fuzzifier ( ) m in equation ( 7) plays an important role in determining values of the typicality matrix. Unlike FCM, where most users pick m 2 = for simplicity, PCM is more sensitive to this choice. They suggested that, as a heuristic rule, m should be chosen less than 2 for best performance. In an attempt to ameliorate the "m problem", they suggested an alternate formulation of the criterion function that eliminates .

m The necessary condition for the cluster centers remains the same, but this approach provides a different sequence of values for U and V heading towards a possible minimum of the modified objective function.

Other formulations of the criterion function for PCM have been proposed, along with their resulting optimization conditions. In [76], convergence of FCM and several of its derivatives, including some versions of PCM, was studied. A generalized formulation of PCM was reported in [77]. Zhou et al. established convergence properties equivalent to those for FCM for three generalized versions of PCM in [78], [79]. Recently a "sparse" version of PCM appeared [80], along with its convergence theory.

In the PCM algorithm, the parameters { } i h in ( 7) have a significant influence on the final partition matrix; they determine the distance from the cluster center at which the membership crosses 0.5 ("the 3db point"). In [75] Krishnapuram and Keller gave two recommendations for choosing the { } i h based on an initialization using FCM for a few iterations to get a reasonable starting partition. One form is simply the weighted average of all the distances of the input vectors to the i-th cluster center; the second choice computes the average distance of "good" i-th cluster points, that is, points that belong to ana level cut of the cluster. Of course, now you have to decide what level cut to use, but it does add flexibility. For data sets where there might be more noise, the estimates can be done at the end of each iteration of the PCM algorithm. In the case of very noisy data, running FCM may not (probably won't) result in good starting points for PCM.

Because PCM tends to search for dense regions of feature space it can have the property that more than one cluster center, and hence the clusters themselves, end up being identical. While this has been cited as a bad property by some, it can be a good trait in situations where the exact number of clusters is unknown. A larger number of clusters than "expected" can be specified as the initial value for , c and then identical clusters can be pruned if they arise. In [81], Yang and Lai propose to exploit this idea by having all points initially serve as cluster centers and then constructing an automatic merging PCM (AM-PCM). AM-PCM is a deterministic algorithm once the parameters are set, and so the key is to study the parameter setting.
The fact that all points (or some gridding of feature space) are used as initial cluster centers is a major issue in scaling up this algorithm to large datasets and/or high dimensionality.

The original PCM is quite robust in identifying outliers, a challenge to AM-PCM, whereas that algorithm tends to produce superior soft partitions for clean data. In fact, this duality was exploited in an initialization scheme for streaming clustering, i.e., situations where the data comes in sequentially over time. In [82], after collecting vectors for some preliminary time, PCM with c chosen larger than the expected number of starting clusters was run essentially to identify outliers in this early grouping. Co-incident clusters were no problem here. Then, with the outliers tagged, AM-PCM was run to get a good initial partition. A Gaussian Mixture Model was used and updated as each new point arrived, logging anomalies. PCM was applied to the anomaly list to check for the emergence of new clusters. This approach was extended to utilize an incremental validity measure [83] that actually serves as a means to understand what the clustering process is actually doing.

PCM decouples the search for clusters into a parallel hunt, so it is one of the few approaches that can look for just one cluster at a time. This first came up when Professor Zadeh called Keller and posed the challenge "Jim, how do you define a cluster?" His own answer was that if you want to say whether a bunch of points form a cluster (whatever that really means), you have to use memberships. That challenge inspired the work reported in [84] that used P1M with varying values of h to construct a membership function for The idea that PCM can look for one cluster at a time formed the basis of a sequential version of P1M [85], [86] to attack the regular clustering problem, with the second paper addressing that nagging question of how to "pick h ".

div.head: Models and Algorithms for Relational Data
div.p: All of the methods discussed in previous sections can be couched in terms of relational data via the expedient of converting X to D, i.e., ( , ) . o o D x x diss i j ij i j = = -However, many applications provide relational data directly. For example, information retrieval problems are often cast in this similar vein; Dij corresponds to the occurrence of keyword i in document .

j Space limits what we can say about fuzzy relational clustering algorithms, but this topic at least deserves recognition, because ~ again ~ Zadeh was at the forefront of this line of research, and our aim is to show how pervasive his ideas became in fuzzy clustering.

Zadeh [21] showed how to use matrix multiplication in ( ) O n 4 time to find the max-min transitive closure of a symmetric, reflexive fuzzy relation and use it for clustering using "a-cuts". Tamura et al. [87] gave a different method that is at worst ( ) log O n n 3 and at best . ( ) O n 3 Kandel and Yelowitz discussed a fuzzy version of Warshall's algorithm for computing the transitive closure [88]. Dunn [37] gave an ( ) O n 2 algorithm for constructing the max-min transitive closure of a symmetric, reflexive fuzzy relation. Miyamoto proved the equivalence between the partitions generated by four different fuzzy relational algorithms [89]. These graph-theoretic methods have been particularly effective in information retrieval, where they were used, for example, to construct fuzzy thesauri [90]- [94]. See [95], [96] for a different decompositional method of fuzzy relational clustering based on convex decompositions of fuzzy partitions.

There are also a number of models and algorithms which generate a fuzzy partition from relational data based on minimization of an objective function. The first method of this type has already been discussed [12], [13]. Roubens developed an early method called fuzzy non-metric (FNM) clustering in [97]. Windham presented a generalized method called assignmentprototypes (AP) clustering in [98]. The reformulation theorem [99], which eliminates V from (6a) instead of U, was used in [100] and [101] to define and analyze relational duals of the FCM objective functions called relational fuzzy c-means (RFCM). AP and FNM require one less assumption on the relational data than RFCM. Thus, the AP and FNM models have a wider reach in applications than RFCM. A relational version of PCM is presented in [102].

Finally, we would be remiss in our obligations to the fuzzy clustering community without mentioning some of the exciting new areas that have arisen in the 21st Century. We don't have space to provide even cursory reviews, but we want to acknowledge ongoing efforts in these new areas, all of which evolved from Zadeh's ideas about fuzzy sets. Subspace methods [103]; kernel methods [104]; swarm-based methods [105]; fuzzy clustering in Big Data [106]; Streaming data [107], Ensemble clustering [108]; Clustering in Fuzzy Graphs [109]; and Visualization [110]. Space also precludes discussion of one of the most important spinoffs of fuzzy clustering, viz., fuzzy cluster validity, but every paper in this field is also a natural extension of Zadeh's idea.

div.head: Epilogue
div.p: Our topic has become a vast enterprise, occupying thousands of researchers who have published dozens of thousands of papers directly or indirectly related to fuzzy cluster analysis. And of course our review reflects our own biases and work, since those are the most familiar to us. It is simply impossible to account for all of the important papers that have appeared in the 21st century, so we apologize here for the many omissions our article has made. Moreover, the number of threads in the current fabric of our topic make even categorization by topic a nearly impossible challenge. But we feel that the intention of this review-to acknowledge the breadth and depth to which Lotfi Zadeh's idea about the mathematical representation of uncertainty has influenced the field of cluster analysis-has been served.

figure.figDesc: Nhc is the canonical (unit vector) basis of Euclidean c-space, so , the i-th vertex of , Nhc is the crisp label for class i. The nondegenerate (no zero rows) possibilistic, fuzzy/probabilistic and crisp c-partitions of n objects are matrices in the following sets:

depicts the three sets of label vectors for . c The origin in Fig.3is at the tail of the arrow depicting the centroid vector . y r Fig.4is a stylized visualization of the relationship between the crisp and fuzzy c-partitions on n objects. Each vertex in this diagram represents a c n # matrix. If we relax the row membership constraint u and call these two supersets M 0 fcn and , M 0 hcn they are the degenerate crisp and fuzzy c-partitions on n objects. The degenerate (one or more zero rows) and non-degenerate (no zero rows) crisp c-partitions on n objects comprise all of the vertices of the "soccer ball" in Fig.4. Mathematically, the degenerate fuzzy partitions are a convex polytope, viz., M 0 fcn is the convex hull of ,

Many clustering models and algorithms are called "k-means" or "c-means." The most heavily documented and widely used of these are the batch (global) hard c-means (HCM) model; and the sequential (local) sHCM model. The confusion between the two models and algorithms to optimize them is exacerbated by many authors who refer to either simply as "k-means" without bothering to identify which version is meant. The main difference between HCM and sHCM is that the sequential version considers local structure in the data one point at a time, whereas the batch HCM model tries to capture the global relationship between all the vectors in X. The objective function and optimization problem defining the classical hard c-means (HCM, aka "k-means") model are
is a user-defined set of weights. This family imbeds the FCM and HCM objective functions. Specifically, when h
